subject: Host reboot configuration support
commitMessage:
Host reboot configuration support

Redfish API now supports a mechanism for the users of the system
to configure the number of times a BMC should restart the host
firmware when in an error path before giving up. Originally
the function "attemptsLeft(uint32_t)" ignored the passed in value
and and always set this number to a hardcoded 3(without the user
knowing). Changes made here allow for this property to be set by
an external user over D-bus for values other than 3.

To compliment this functionality and the new DBus property
"RetryAttempts" an override was created to ensure that when
"RetryAttempts" is set by an external user that the "AttemptsLeft"
property is updated accordingly.

Versioning was added to avoid a serialization error that
would occur if a system was loaded using the previous version that did
not include this new property.

Testing:
  - Using the newly defined cereal version of '2' performed correctly.
  - Removing the new property and reverting cereal class version back
    to '1' behaved properly.
  - built and ran with Docker along with the web changes.
  - verified update of "AttemptsLeft" through a p10bmc running
    on simics through busctl.
  - verified that when the "RetryAttempts" policy value is changed by
    either bmcweb or dbus set-property() that "AttemptsLeft" updates
    accordingly.

busctl set-property xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host ... RetryAttempts u 1
busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host ... RetryAttempts
service@p10bmc: u 1

busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host ... AttemptsLeft
service@p10bmc: u 1

busctl set-property xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host ... RetryAttempts u 3
busctl set-property xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host ... AttemptLeft u 8
busctl get-property xyz.openbmc_project.State.Host ... AttemptLeft u 3
service@p10bmc: u 3

Signed-off-by: Corey Hardesty <corey.hardesty@icloud.com>
Change-Id: I70a8457c88fb76e118937d79e8dbe15518df7264

nit: no "-" between words. This is just a normal summary sentence.
Ack

Please provide a bit more high level info on the "Why" here. So high level summary here is that the Redfish API now provides a mechanism for the user of the system to configure the number of times the BMC should restart the host firmware in error paths before giving up. Previously the BMC code had just hard coded this to 3 so even if someone provided a different value over D-Bus for this property, the code would always set it to 3. Your change here is now allowing external users to actually set it to something other then 3.
Ack
Please update this once test is complete
Done

Patrick, you were the original proponent on not allowing the host the ability to configure it's own reboot count, and stated it was a BMC controlled policy. With there now being a Redfish API to set this, we're going to change that design. Let me know if you have any concerns.
Should "BOOT_COUNT_MAX_ALLOWED" be here or removed?

I think we leave it for this commit. We need to default it to something on initial startup. Although I could see the argument for us adding this to our cereal (saved/restored) data. So if a user changes it, we persist that change. So lets plan on another commit after this that adds this to our save/restore data using the cereal class below.
That's what I was thinking in terms on initialization. Better to ask than to be sorry! Will look into the cereal data before testing.
ok, so the resolution to this one is that we now preserve, and restores the retryAttempts property. Similar to other setting which are preserved in this code using the Cereal class.

I added the properties to the cereal save/load. Should I change the property attemptsLeft to default to 3 in PDI so it's initialized before the Host is instantiated? Don't really see a drawback to initializing it before runtime.

It should just be initialized to whatever retryAttempts is. retryAttempts will be loaded either a value from storage in determineInitialState() or it will be the default you set in the PDI interface. Since your function to set retryAttempts also sets attemptsLeft, you can just delete this line of code.
Done
Please update function documentation.
Ack
It seems pointless to even `overrride` this function then.  Just let the original binding generated one do its thing, right?
Yes, the override is basically pointless here. I wasn't audacious enough to completely remove the override.
Done
This comment is no longer true.
don't know how I missed that....
CI failure due to the new PDI not being present in the jenkins build.
I think you can remove this "in"
Done

So we've gotta leave this interface. It's used in multiple spots in the code base. A user can still come in an reset the number of attemptsLeft. But instead of it hard coding "3" it should just set it to whatever retryAttempts is set to.
Done
Changing this should be
?? I'm guessing this was a precursor to your logging comment on #117.
Done
Changing this should be very rare, I'd like a "info" log that this change has occurred and what the new value is.
Done

I don't think we should preserve the attemptsLeft property. I'd prefer that always just get defaulted to whatever retryAttempts is. Who knows the scenario of why this application has been reset, and when, so best to just start fresh with the number of reboots the host has available.
Ack
Is there a reason to not use the generic "VALUE" keyword?  I can't imagine there is a lot of value in a unique name for this.
Was trying to be as concrete as possible. Acknowledged!

Are you intentionally ignoring the value still?

I suspect this line is to shut up a linter.  Can we simply remove 'value' (leave uint32_t) or add the [[maybe_unused]] attribute?

Just removed value. Reason being [[maybe_unused]] probably isn't the best for this situation. I think that would be best for a potentially unused variable. There is no reason to be using "value". The only case where it would be convenient would be to check if value is equal to retryAttempts to avoid the set. However, I'm still retrieving the value of retryAttempts regardless, so might as well just set the property with whatever retryAttempts is and totally ignore the value.
Done

I think now that we actually want the value, you need to do what you did for retryAttempts and define a variable here, and set that (i.e. uint32_t value) in function declaration and then set that for attemptsLeft.

So to be clear, wouldn't the override not even be needed in that case? 
At this point the only difference between this override and regular behavior would be the debug message generated.
Done

I'm not sure how Cereal works, but it may require the new field be at the end. One use case would be a system has the previous file, that only has the 3 entries in it. Your new code runs, which tries to load 4 entries from it. What's the behavior? Does it error on all of them, or restore the 3 and just ignore that the 4th that is not there. Once your code runs to store the values, the file will be good, so it's just that first case we need to think about. May be best to manually stop the state service, manipulate the file to only have 3, and see what happens when you start your code. The file is out in /var/lib/phosphor-state-manager/

Due to have issues launching simics(at the end of the day I was passing a bunch of flags that were unneeded, default worked PERFECTLY). Anyways I changed the cereal save/load to adding only retry attempts onto the end and removed attempts left entirely. I'm thinking I can create another cereal class version to distinguish between these two cases? Cereal was working properly in this way however, the bmc did queisce once when I tested removing the retry attempts value from the "runninghosttransition" file that was generated by cereal.
I take the quiesce comment back. I don't know what I did originally but when replicating the bmc was in a weird state where it kept transitioning from on to off. Regardless it needs to be fixed.
I was testing another change in the same simics instance. Even when removing the newly added cereal entry "retryattempts" the bmc came back online properly. disregard previous comments.
Done

So, it seems to me like on a fresh boot of a system, it will not have retryAttemps set in the archive file initially. So do we read a 0 in that case? Are we then writing a 0 for retryAttemps? I wonder if we need a check to see if it's 0 and if it is, write the default value we read from PDI to it instead? To test, just stop the host state service, remove the cereal file from /var/lib/, start the host state app, and read the retryAttempts from D-Bus.

I did some extensive testing with this to get results for most cases.
1. On a fresh boot "RetryAttempts" is set to the PDI default of 3.
2. When the 'obmc-host-stop@0.target' is started and the host service is stopped and restarted(after modifying the cereal file) the proper value for retry attempts is loaded and added to dbus.
3. When the host service is stopped and the `obmc-host-stop@0.target' is invoked(to generate the cereal file) and the value is removed I hit a de-serialize exception. RetryAttempts loses it's user set value and resorts back to the default of 3.
4. When the file is deleted and the host is started back up, RetryAttempts(and all other properties) resort back to their default state.

So the issue that we're reading 0 most likely isn't the case since I don't believe that would cause a de-serialization error. The error must be coming from serial trying to read a value but reading EOF instead. I think the fix will be to use the previously voided cereal version so that the correct load operation is performed. I'll also have to reach out to Patrick about potentially using the [maybe_unused] for the load function, however I don't know if that will work nicely with the cereal template.

https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/phosphor-state-manager/+/53603
Changed the cereal version. Added a conditional such that if we do hit the case where the BMC tries to boot with the earlier version '1' the load template will
respond accordingly.
Done
This is needed for instantiation to set the property to the max-allowed.
Not anymore... ;)
Ack
Do you need a `min(value, retryAttempts)` ?  I'm not saying you do but just asking since it seems like a possibility.

I didn't think to implement any logic since the unsigned type would prevent a negative value from being passed. However,this does make me think some logic should be added here to ensure attemptsLeft is not set to a value greater than retryAttempts(MAX_BOOT_COUNT_ALLOWED).
As far as a 'min' I don't think that would completely apply since the use case may be to set the attemptsLeft back to the value of retryAttempts after experiencing a couple of unsuccessful boots. That may produce undesired behavior for someone working on the machine. Don't think checking to make sure attemptsLeft cannot be set to zero makes much sense since it is a valid request.

> As far as a 'min' I don't think that would completely apply since the use case may be to set the attemptsLeft back to the value of retryAttempts after experiencing a couple of unsuccessful boots.

I'm not really following this comment.  min(value, retryAttempts) would be value unless value > retryAttempts.  This is just a clamp to make sure someone cannot set attemptsLeft > retryAttempts.  Again, I don't know if you need it but you seem to imply that you do by this:

> However,this does make me think some logic should be added here to ensure attemptsLeft is not set to a value greater than retryAttempts(MAX_BOOT_COUNT_ALLOWED).

In my opinion `min` would do exactly that.  Can you describe a case where it wouldn't?
Corey, I think Patrick is just asking you to use the c++ algorithm "min" - https://cplusplus.com/reference/algorithm/min/ vs. writing your own logic for it.
I don't know how I left Patrick's commented unattended to. Sorry, I must have glanced over when checking gerrit. Just implemented will push briefly.
Done
Done
I can't believe we made this a meson option, but whatever.  Maybe some cleanup for another day.

I think it'll be rather quick to take out.
This option is only used in host_state_manager.cpp
I'll remove it and make the corresponding changes there in another commit.

I'm struggling to keep track of the reviews a bit here, but I think I had a comment somewhere that I'm not sure why you removed this and put it in the header file? Why not just change it to 2 in the meson files?
Ack

Drop.  

I'm not sure how you keep ending up with these sneaking in.  Something funny with your set up?
it's when I cherry pick and amend, I usually catch it. Will have to change my git.config.
Done

I know you just moved this comment from the old code but it is kind of silly.  We have a constant, which is defined and controlled elsewhere, but then we add English text with the value here.

I'd probably write "just set to the default (BOOT_COUNT_MAX_ALLOWED)".
Ack
... especially considering 3 is just the default in a meson-option and not even a hard-coded constant.
Ack
I think we agreed this would be a separate commit
I need to remove this from the commit, it is no longer valid.
